awd_abstract_narration:
Harford Community College's High Intensity Student Engagement Model (HIStEM) will provide scholarships and co-curricular support to up to 42 academically talented students with financial need in biology and engineering. The program will function to increase the number of students completing associate's degrees in biology and engineering and facilitate their transfer into a four-year college or university to continue their STEM studies, thereby addressing the need for qualified STEM professionals in the workforce.  

The HIStEM program will provide up to 14 scholarships each year to students who demonstrate financial need, possess high academic potential, and are enrolled full-time. The goals of the HIStEM program are to increase the retention and graduation rates  with an associate's degree of biology and engineering students and facilitate their successful transfer to a four-year institution. Students will be supported through a cohort learning community and activities aimed at increasing student-faculty interactions and engagement in the college and scientific communities.  Activities will include the assignment of a personal faculty mentor and an academic advisor to provide academic and professional advising, opportunities to network with STEM professionals and engage in independent research, course redesigns, and sessions in academic skills development. Through the use of institutional research data and student surveys, the program will measure the effectiveness of increased student-faculty engagement activities on the retention and graduation rates of biology and engineering students at Harford Community College and their subsequent transfer to a four-year institution.

por.por_cntn:
The Harford Community College S-STEM Scholarship program, High-Intensity Student Engagement Model (HISTEM) program, was implemented to provide scholarships, mentoring, and support services to academically promising and financially needy full-time students pursuing their Associate in Science or Associate in Applied Science degree in a STEM program. Eligible STEM programs included biology, chemistry, computer information systems, computer science, data science, engineering, environmental science, information assurance and cybersecurity, mathematics, and physics.

The objectives of the HISTEM program were: (1) To identify, recruit, and provide scholarships to academically talented students interested in STEM with demonstrated financial need; (2) Retain and graduate at least 70% of the STEM majors in the HISTEM program by providing increased student-faculty engagement through faculty mentors, academic and career supports, and funded research experiences; (3) Facilitate the successful transfer of at least 70% of the STEM majors in the HISTEM program to a four-year institution or entry into the workforce.

During the grant period (2017 to 2024), the HISTEM program supported 68 HISTEM Scholars with scholarships ranging from $500 to $10,000. Additionally, funding was provided for summer research experiences and attendance at national conferences and meetings. At the end of the grant period, at least 52 students (76.5%) completed the program and either transferred to a four-year college or entered the STEM workforce, 3 switched to a non-STEM program, 3 dropped from the program due to academic ineligibility, 3 left the college for undocumented reasons, and 5 continued in the program post-grant. 47% of the awardees were women.

Each HISTEM scholars was paired with a faculty mentor within their academic discipline and a designated STEM academic advisor. Faculty mentors met with the HISTEM scholars three times each semester for academic/career planning and student success strategies. Workshops on time management, study strategies, searching for internships and research experience, resume writing, networking, and career planning were offered three to four times each semester. A STEM networking event hosted by the Society of Military Engineers with local STEM professionals was organized twice a year. The annual external evaluations consistently reported that students identified mentoring and workshops on skill builidng, resume writing, and searching for internships as the most impactful components of the HISTEM program


Last Modified: 09/28/2024
Modified by: Tamalene J Imbierowicz
